summary.seg: Down to about the end of the 14th century most manuscript books were typically made either by professional scribes working for hire, or by some who would practise the craft by vocation, in religious houses or other ecclesiastical environments. Thereafter, it became increasingly common for a variety of lay persons (lawyers, merchants, estate managers, the numerous unbeneficed clergy, and the like) to construct and copy manuscripts for their own use, or for that of a small circle of associates, such as a household or a family. The spread of pragmatic literacy among professionals, for such purposes as accounting and correspondence, rapidly increased the circulation of paper as the preferred material for writing, and the making of books as a means of keeping texts useful for many practical purposes, or for edification or entertainment, became common practice. The physical construction of such manuscripts was often accretive, the compiler accumulating a series of paper gatherings and booklets as exemplars became available. When sufficient material was to hand it might be put into a hard binding, but it might equally be stitched into a vellum wrapper (resembling a modern paperback), or kept loose in a folder. MS Ll.1.18 at Cambridge University Library (hereafter 'Ll') is a good example of the kind of 'home-made' books that must have become very common in the 15th century, though because of their ephemeral character and vulnerable supports, relatively few have survived.

Though the identity of Ll's compiler remains unknown, recent research has shown that he was someone very likely to have been involved, in various practical ways, in the running of the archbishop of York's palace at Southwell, in Nottinghamshire. The bulkiest item in his varied collection of texts is a formulary (a set of templates for legal documents) which drew for its exemplars on the archive of William Booth, archbishop of York from 1452 to 1464, a clergyman very active in both the ecclesiastical and political spheres through the mid-15th century. This suggests that the compiler probably had clerical responsibilities in the archbishop's household. Other items in the manuscript indicate that catering and welfare were also part of his remit. They include sets of culinary receipts, some of them distinctly up-market, and perhaps suitable for the archiepiscopal table, together with a variety of medical prescriptions, which point to some of the risks to health at the time. These include remedies intended to ward off the repeated visitations of the plague, and also for a new disease, the deadly sweating sickness, first recorded in England in 1469. As befitted a high-status household, the compiler also had by him manuals for the care and exercise of horses, hounds and hawks, reminding us that the English clergy's passion for the chase extended over many centuries.

Ll rewards study from a variety of angles, and further work in the archives of Southwell and of the archbishops of York may yet reveal exactly who its compiler was. He seems to have been especially associated with William Worseley, a prebendary of Southwell (and later dean of St Paul's, London), a fact unexpectedly revealed when one reverses the image of a draft letter to Worseley, which the compiler amused himself by penning in mirror-writing on folio 81r.

Richard Beadle
Professor of Medieval English Literature and Palaeography emeritus
St John's College, Cambridge

msContents.textLang: Middle English and Latin. Middle English with dialectical features locatable to Midlands and Nottinghamshire [LALME]

msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae (in English)
msItem.incipit: 3r: as in þe sekenesse do be tyme as hit is sayde in þe se
msItem.explicit: 3r: made hole and fare well
msItem.note: Begins imperfectly. Only four lines, of the end of the short version of the Middle English translation of John of Burgundy's plague tract.

msItem.title: Recipes and dietary advice against the plague
msItem.rubric: 3r: medicin
msItem.incipit: 3r: Hit hath ben taght in tyme off pestilence for a souerayn
msItem.explicit: 4v: cornyll hard aboue þe flesch then lay on hym plasters to brese hit
msItem.note: Loss of text on f. 4r-4v owing to damage to the manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: Singer and Anderson (1950), p. 94, no. 63 (using this manuscript)

msItem.title: Charm against pestilence
msItem.textLang: Latin, with one line of Middle English
msItem.incipit: 4v: Afuge tu subito procul esto tarde redito
msItem.explicit: 4v: Aufrige peste cito procul et tarde reuenito
msItem.note: Added to the bottom margin by a 15th- or early 16th-century hand. Four lines; third line in Middle English.

msItem.title: The Governaile of Health
msItem.rubric: 6r: Off þe profette Off godes gouernayll
msItem.incipit: 6r: Hit nedyth hym þat wyll lyve long to know þe crafte off
msItem.explicit: 13v: leve þay schall not start þe stroke etc
msItem.note: Printed by Caxton in 1490; reprinted by de Worde in 1506.

msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: Epistle CDLXVI, 'De cura et modo rei familiaris utilius gubernandae, et qualiter patres familias debeant se habere'
msItem.rubric: 14r: Epistola bernardi de disposicione familie
msItem.incipit: 14r: Glorioso et felici Raymundo domino castri Ambrosij bernardus in senium
msItem.explicit: 15v: ad quem ipsam perducat suae dampnabilis senectus amen

msItem.title: Dietary for noble households
msItem.textLang: Middle English, with some rubrics in Latin, and occasional words in French
msItem.rubric: 16r: Hyt is to be Remembret off þe dayly dietez in lordes and ladies howsez For to be kepette
msItem.incipit: 16r: dietes pro die dominica . þat is to say on sunday for my lordez or ladyes
msItem.explicit: 17r: stondyng þis a poyntement
msItem.note: Dietary regimen for the successive days of the week, which are indicated in the margins.

msItem.title: Moral observations on seven types of fool
msItem.rubric: 17r: Septem sunt stulti
msItem.incipit: 17r: Primus est qui tantum minatur quod ipse usu timetur
msItem.explicit: 17r: Septimus est qui tantum se exaltat quod ab aliis necligitur seu deprimitur
msItem.note: Formula adapted from that commonly used for enumerations of the seven vices and virtues. Unprinted and apparently otherwise unrecorded.

msItem.title: Moral observations on seven types of courteousness
msItem.rubric: 17v: Septem sunt principales curialitates
msItem.incipit: 17v: Prima est in priuato sobrietas
msItem.explicit: 17v: Septima inter prospera et aduersa modesta animi fertilitas
msItem.note: Formula adapted from that commonly used for enumerations of the seven vices and virtues. Unprinted and apparently otherwise unrecorded.

msItem.title: Moral observations on six types of uncouthness
msItem.rubric: 17v: Sex sunt principales rusticitates
msItem.incipit: 17v: Prima est beneficii accept oblimo
msItem.explicit: 17v: Sexta cum necessitas fuerit obduracio
msItem.note: Formula adapted from that commonly used for enumerations of the seven vices and virtues. Unprinted and apparently otherwise unrecorded.

msItem.title: An ordinance of pottage (extracts)
msItem.note: 136 culinary recipes in the list of chapters, but 127 in the collection that follows, largely due to loss of two leaves following f. 26.

msItem.title: List of chapters
msItem.rubric: 19r: Here begynneth the chapetours and the ordinance off potage flechmetes bakenmetes fryetmetes gelys lechis and sotelteys the quych was compyleit by maysteris off fysyke and mayster cokys off kyng Rycherd þe fyrst of þe devysyng off ryall potage sleyng off wyldfole and sawsyng off hem þe quych are contenet in a table here aftyr folewynge et cetera
msItem.incipit: 19r: In primis for to make oystyrs in gravy
msItem.explicit: 19v: Baken quynce wyne barre clerrye

msItem.title: Text
msItem.rubric: 20r: For to make oystyrs in gravy
msItem.incipit: 20r: Take oystyrs and putt hem in to a pott with her awne sewe
msItem.explicit: 42r: and lette yt renne thero a bag lyke as þou doyst ypocras

msItem.title: Culinary recipes
msItem.rubric: 42v: Here begynneth the rewle and the ordinance off sleyng off almaner wyldfole off hole fote and clofe fote and sawsyng for hem and the sleyng off fawr foted bestez and the sawsyng for hem et cetera
msItem.incipit: 42v: For crane . Take a crane and lette hym blode
msItem.explicit: 44v: pouder gynger and salte
msItem.note: A series of 23 culinary recipes, mostly for game birds and animals, similar to those included in An ordinance of pottage (nos 140-68).

msItem.title: Terms of association
msItem.incipit: 44v: A herde off hertis
msItem.explicit: 45r: A rysyng of rebellez and or of shrewez
msItem.note: 74 entries, in three columns.

msItem.title: List of wines
msItem.rubric: 45r: Vinum de Burdeux et aliis locis
msItem.incipit: 45r: Rede wyne . White wyne . Taynte
msItem.explicit: 45r: Ossey . Rochell
msItem.note: Unprinted.

msItem.title: List of ingredients
msItem.incipit: 45r: Tyre i butte . s . lxvi lager iiii libri vi s viii d
msItem.explicit: 45r: Grene gynger i li x d
msItem.note: List of spices, with quantities and prices. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Culinary recipes
msItem.rubric: 45v: Here begynneth the sleynge off fysshis and the sethynge and the sawcynge off hem as yt is here after wryton
msItem.incipit: 45v: For codlynge hake or haddok
msItem.explicit: 47v: softe fyre þen boyle hit and serue forthe
msItem.note: A series of 24 culinary recipes for salt and fresh water fish and crustaceans. Cf. the fish section in An ordinance of pottage (nos 169-89). Unprinted.

msItem.title: The Tretyse of Huntyng
msItem.rubric: 48r: Here begynneth the tretyse off huntyng
msItem.incipit: 48r: Hyt es to wyten þat atte þe dore off þe kenell is þe begynnyng of huntyng
msItem.explicit: 55r: þe chyne off an holyfaunt
msItem.note: Not otherwise recorded.

msItem.title: Prince Edward's Book of Hawking (abbreviated version)
msItem.rubric: 55v: Here begynneth þe tretyse off hawkyng
msItem.incipit: 55v: Fyryst she is an neye and disclosyth and hathe hawkez
msItem.explicit: 58v: fynd mo fesauntez and let her flye to hem et cetera
msItem.note: One of several abbreviated adaptations of Prince Edward's Book of Hawking. The last two pages are written on an added slip of paper (f. 58) of smaller dimensions than the surrounding leaves.

msItem.title: Tretyse off the sekenes off haukes
msItem.rubric: 59r: Here begynneth the tretyse off the sekenes off haukes and off þe salues and remedyes for þe sayd sekenessez
msItem.incipit: 59r: For to make salue for hawkes
msItem.explicit: 61v: ij dayes after gyff her sporge and þat shall open her bowels
msItem.note: Collection of 23 recipes for the care of hawks. Not otherwise recorded. Ends imperfectly due to the loss of the following leaf.

The fragments of text on f. 63r and 63v also appear to be recipes for animal care, 'probably for the care of hawks, and so likely to constitute a continuation of the same text' as the above (Connolly, IMEP).

msItem.title: Veterinary recipes for horses
msItem.note: The loss of most of f. 64 and large parts of f. 65 means that the text begins very imperfectly, and no meaningful incipit can be provided. Similarly, the loss of the leaf after f. 73 indicates that the text also ends imperfectly. What remains is a series of thirty-eight of more recipes for the care of horses, which bears a resemblance to The proprytees and medcynes for hors printed by Wynkyn de Worde, ?1502 (STC 20439.3) (cf. Connolly, IMEP).

msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae (adaptation)
msItem.rubric: 74r: Memorandum Henrici iiijti viijo facta fuit per eosdem missa maiori ciuitates londonarum vbi per phisicos apothecarios et alios quam plures maxime laudata
msItem.incipit: 74r: Dilectissime frater vt intellexi multum times pro instanti pestilencia
msItem.explicit: 75v: ab omnibus speciebus calidis et cetera
msItem.note: An unattributed Latin adaptation of John of Burgundy's plague treatise, here addressed to the mayor of London in 1407.

msItem.title: Dietary regimen against pestilence
msItem.incipit: 75v: And so be þat ye be takyn with þe pestilence
msItem.explicit: 76v: not to small and putte hyt in a bagge et cetera

msItem.title: Medical recipe against plague
msItem.rubric: 76v: Pro pestilencia . medicina probata
msItem.incipit: 76v: Take vij croppes off betan v croppes off sage marygeldes rewe and wermote off ichon iij croppes Iste medicine fuerunt exparte per Magistrum Gillan le Gardines et bene valent et cetera
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.textLang: Middle English, with rubric in Latin
msItem.rubric: 76v: Pro morbo caduco medicina
msItem.incipit: 76v: Take þe blode off hys lytyll fynger
msItem.explicit: 76v: and let þe chyld drynk yt and he shall be hole
msItem.note: Magi charm for the falling evil.

msItem.title: Medical advice and recipes
msItem.rubric: 77r: Incipit nobilis tractatus de colleccione medicinarum
msItem.incipit: 77r: Collecciones eciam consideraciones et scientia medico
msItem.explicit: 79v: istam corpus curatur et cetera
msItem.note: Unprinted.

msItem.title: ?Medical ?recipe / ?charm
msItem.note: Crossed out and not now legible. Begins in Latin, ends in Middle English.

msItem.title: Mirror writing and cipher
msItem.note: Originally blank. It now contains two lines in mirror writing, comprising most of a draft of a short personal letter, and two lines written in code, of similar character, both added by the main scribe of the manuscript. See 'Item transcription' below for further details.

msItem.title: Notes on mortal sins
msItem.incipit: 81v: Beda dicit quod sacredos qui est sine peccato mortali
msItem.explicit: 81v: quod loquitur ore
msItem.note: Brief notes on mortal sin, attributed to Bede and Gregory. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Legal formulary
msItem.author: William Booth
msItem.rubric: 82r: Exemplaria obligacionum indenturarum et huiusmodi
msItem.incipit: 82r: Nouerint vniuersi per presentes nos
msItem.explicit: 123v: ecclesie cath. lych[field] william E
msItem.note: Legal formulary, described as follows by Baker and Ringrose (1996), pp. 435-36: 'precedents of instruments, mostly made by William Booth as bishop of Coventry (1447-52) or as archbishop of York (1452-64), including conditional bonds and leases. On 83r is a bond dated 10 January (1458), 36 Hen. VI; on 85v is lease of lead mines in Hexham by Booth, as archbishop of York, to William Bee, and on 88r-v are two arbitration awards in English by Booth as bishop of Chester (i.e. bishop of Lichfield and Coventry) in August (1452), 30 Hen. VI, the first concerning lands in Cannock, Staffs., and the second settling a suit for defamation in the consistory court. From 90r the instruments are mostly ecclesiastical'. Several of the instruments are given or dated at Southwell (Notts.), and relate to persons connected with the collegiate church, notably members of the Worsley family; cf. 81r and 130r-130v. Unprinted. Two leaves are wanting at the end. On ff. 91v-92v is a cumulative tabulation of monetary values by the day, week, month and year.

msItem.title: Legal formulae
msItem.rubric: 126r: Posicionones et articuli
msItem.incipit: 126r: In dei nomine amen posiciones et articulos infrascriptur
msItem.explicit: 127v: vt premittitur contractum parentes A.
msItem.note: Unprinted.

msItem.title: Political prophecy
msItem.incipit: 128r: And lx yen barons full bolde shall be brittand to dethe
msItem.explicit: 128v: What juggement þe justice will juge hem to have
msItem.note: 45 lines of alliterative verse, possibly concerned with the career of James I of Scotland (d. 1437).

msItem.title: De re militari (Middle English) (extracts)
msItem.author: Nicholas Upton
msItem.rubric: 129r: De Armis
msItem.incipit: 129r: A fers is a barre a pilet or a pile is blak a besande
msItem.explicit: 129v: H Lancaster Rex haraldorum in partibus borialibus
msItem.note: Notes on heraldic terms and animals. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Household accounts (?model)
msItem.note: Set of accounts (probably intended as a model, since no year is given), originally relating to a household at Southwell (Notts.). Headings for 'Panetria', 'Butteria', 'Coquina', 'Pullettria', 'Salsaria', 'Focale' and 'Stabulum'. cf. f. 81v. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: For the swetynge seknes
msItem.note: Remedy against the sweating sickness added by a later hand, unprinted. The first recorded outbreak of the disease in England took place in 1483, and it returned periodically until 1551.

msItem.title: De re militari (Latin) (extracts)
msItem.author: Nicholas Upton
msItem.incipit: 131r: De coloribus in armis depictis et eorum nobilitate
msItem.explicit: 134v: corrigant et emendant
msItem.note: Extracts from Nicholas Upton's De re militari, divided into three distinct sections: ff. 131r-133v contains brief extracts from Books III and IV, mostly crudely drawn shields in monochrome, probably copied from from a better quality illuminated copy of the text; ff. 133v-134v contain the prologue and the dedication to Humfrey, duke of Gloucester (d. 1447) (corresponding to pp. 1-3 in the printed edition); on f. 134v is the epilogue (pp. 258-59).

msItem.title: Annals
msItem.rubric: 138r: Infra hanc tabulam hec continentur Cronice breuiter tacte
msItem.incipit: 138r: Anni ab orbe condito ad vrbem rome conditam
msItem.explicit: 140v: Anno eodem Ricardus filius princeps Edwardi coronatus fuit apud Westmonasterium
msItem.note: List of contents at the beginning also notes 'Discriptio corporis christi et beate marie, Originalia diuersorum doctorum, Sanctorum loca vel peregrinaciones, Mirabilia orientis et occidentis', which follow this text.
Ends imperfectly. There are two leaves missing after f. 140, and the top half of f. 139 has been torn off, carrying away part of the text. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Remissions from purgatory
msItem.incipit: 144r: approbauit et impeniet tot dies
msItem.explicit: 144r: Summa per annum ix mlccc annos
msItem.note: Eight lines, the ending of the 'Discriptio corporis christi et beate marie' mentioned in the list of contents on f. 138r. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Extracts from the Fathers
msItem.rubric: 144rOriginalia doctorum
msItem.incipit: 144r: Superbia demones fecit ex angilis
msItem.explicit: 145r: non poterit animam
msItem.note: Brief extracts from the Fathers of the Church, whose names are listed in the margins (Gregory, Augustine etc.). Mentioned in the list of contents on f. 138r. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Holy sites and pilgrimage destinations
msItem.rubric: 145r: Sanctorum loca
msItem.incipit: 145r: In primis sanctum corpus beate marie in valle josaphat
msItem.explicit: 145v: Iuxta viterbuini iacet virgo et martir sancta Margareta
msItem.note: Mentioned in the list of contents on f. 138r. Unprinted.

msItem.title: Marvels of the east
msItem.rubric: 146r: Mirabilia orientis
msItem.incipit: 146r: Reuera admirabile est nomine dei in vniuersa terra
msItem.explicit: 147r: vestimenta eius alba vt nix fuerunt
msItem.note: Mentioned in the list of contents on f. 138r. Unprinted.
This item and the next are also found together in Cambridge, St John's College, MS F.18, ff. 131-33.

msItem.title: Marvels of England
msItem.rubric: 147v: Mirabilia anglie
msItem.incipit: 147v: Ventus egreditur cauernus in monte qui dicitur peek
msItem.explicit: 148r: nemo nouit causam
msItem.note: This item and the previous are also found together in Cambridge, St John's College, MS F.18, ff. 131-33.

msItem.title: Notes on kings of England
msItem.incipit: 148r: Postquam saxones et anglici venissent ad alemania ad istam terram
msItem.explicit: 148v: Rex Edwardus burdeus regit [blank] Westmonasterium iacet
msItem.finalRubric: 148v: Isti fuerunt Reges Anglie post conquestum
msItem.note: From Alfred to Edward III.

msItem.title: Notes on the ecclesiastical history of Ireland
msItem.incipit: 149r: Hibernia diuiditur in iiijor vltomiam momoniam mediam et armaciam
msItem.explicit: 149r: Cedda episcopus vita doctrina sanctitate et exemplo

msItem.title: Letter
msItem.author: Edward III
msItem.rubric: 149v Per Regem . Venerabili congregacioni Magistrorum regencium et non Regencium nobis carissimorum Vniuersitatis nostre cantabrigie
msItem.incipit: 149v: Venerabile congregacioni grauissorum virorum Magistrorum regencium
msItem.explicit: xxiiijo die mensis octobris
msItem.note: From Edward IV to the University of Cambridge, written at Pontefract Castle on 24 October (year unstated) .

msItem.title: Letter
msItem.author: Edward IV
msItem.rubric: 150r: To oure ryght trusty and welbelovette þe presydent and þe hoole congrigacion of Regentes and non Regentes off oure vniuersite of cambryg . By þe kyng
msItem.incipit: 150r: Ryght trusty and welbelovette we grete yow hertely
msItem.explicit: 150v: off reson to be doo. Querby þe shall deserue
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly. From Edward IV to the University of Cambridge. Printed in Cooper (vol. 1, 1842, p. 213).

p.material: Paper, folded in quarto, arranged into five booklets (see Collation) formed from one or more of five paper stocks, as follows:

watermark.seg: ɑ/alpha: a geometric design including two concentric circles approximately 25mm in diameter, connected to a triangular motif of some kind. Partially visible in Quires 1 (ff. 3/10), 2 (f. 13), 3 (ff. 19/34, 21/32, 23/30), 4 (ff. 35/61, 38/47, 40/45, 41/44).
ɣ/gamma: unidentifiable, being heavily overlaid with text, and partially visible only once, in Quire 8 (ff. 76/79).
δ/delta: tête-de-boeuf, visible only once, in Quire 9 (ff. 84/87), in which β also appears.

note.p: Roughly speaking, therefore, the first third of the manuscript (Quires 1-4) is probably made up of paper from stock with watermark ɑ/alpha, but includes at least one bifolium from stock bearing watermark β/beta in quire 2, and also includes two small quires on β/beta paper (Quires 5 and 6) inserted into quire 4. Most of the remainder of the manuscript also appears to be made up of β/beta-watermarked paper (Quires 7-14), except for the minor intrusions of bifolia bearing the ɣ/gamma and δ/delta watermarks in Quires 8 and 9. The presence of paper with the β/beta-type watermark throughout almost all the manuscript may possibly contribute to some estimate of its date (perhaps late in or soon after the third quarter of the fifteenth century), and also sheds some light on the compilers' access to materials, and their procedures.

'It will be noted that the predominant paper stock used throughout the manuscript is that designated β above (possibly c. 1469). β appears mixed with ɑ in the first two booklets, and briefly with δ in the fourth, which indicates that though the compiler took time to assemble his texts, his source of writing material mostly remained stable as the work progressed.'

foliation.note: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by H.L. PinkPink, H. L.. Folio numbers 1-2, 5, 18, 27-29, 62, 73, 80, 93, 110, 124-125, 135-137 and 141-143 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). This sequence is used in this record.

Written in pencil in the middle of the upper margin of the recto of each leaf (and later struck through), by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1866)Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886. In several places, Bradshaw cancelled his previous attempt(s) at foliation and re-wrote the numbers, or over-wrote them. Gaps in this sequence are again a consequence of numbers being assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (see also Additions).

Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos (and later struck through), by an unidentified hand of the 19th century (and prior to Bradshaw's foliation). Leaves after f. 29 and f. 30 of this sequence (i.e. current ff. 36 and 39) were accidentally omitted.

Written in ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, in the 15th century, for the Ordinance of pottage, and to which the prefatory list of contents on f. 19r-19v refers. Gaps in the sequence indicate the subsequent loss of leaves (see Collation).

collation.p: '[A]n unknown quantity of material has been lost from both the beginning and the end of the book as it now stands. What we have are the remains of fifteen gatherings (now bound as sixteen), of widely varying lengths. They fall into distinct groups of the kind commonly designated as booklets, five in number, each of which is largely devoted to a particular type of subject matter. Though the process of copying within these larger units seems to have been mostly continuous, differences in appearance from one booklet to the next suggest that the manuscript as a whole was accumulated over a period of time, as material came to hand. As is commonly the case in 'home-made' compilations of this kind, there are few signs that the copyist was much concerned with the more formal procedures involved in book production, such as pricking and ruling, or the provision of quire and leaf signatures, and he had no qualms about inserting new booklets within existing ones.'

Summary of booklets:
Booklet 1 = Quires 1-2 (ff. ['1']-['18'])
Booklet 2 = Quires 3-4, with Quires 5 and 6 inserted after the 13th leaf in Quire 4, and Quire 7 (ff. 19-['73'])
Booklet 3 = Quire 8 (ff. 74-81)
Booklet 4 = Quires 9-13 (ff. 82-['137'])
Booklet 5 = now misbound as Quires 15-16, but originally a single quire (ff. 138-['151'])

Collation formula:
Quire 112-3 (ff. 3-12: 1st, 2nd and 5th leaves, ff. '1-2' and '5', missing)
Quire 26-1 (ff. 13-17: 6th leaf, f. '18', missing)
Quire 316-3 (ff. 19-34: 9th-11th leaves, ff. '27-29', missing)
Quire 416 (ff. 35-47 and 59-61: Quires 5 and 6 inserted after the 13th leaf, f. 47)
Quire 56 (ff. 48-53)
Quire 64+1 (ff. 54-58: 5th leaf, f. 58, inserted)
Quire 712-2 (ff. 63-72: 1st and 12th leaves, ff. '62' and '73', missing)
Quire 88-1 (ff. 74-81: 7th leaf, f. '80', missing)
Quire 98 (ff. 82-89)
Quire 104-1 (ff. 90-92: 4th leaf, f. '93', missing)
Quires 11-128 (ff. 94-110)
Quire 1316-3 (ff. 111-123: 1st, 15th and 16th leaves, ff. '110', '124' and '125', missing)
Quire 1412-3 (ff. 126-134: 10th-12th leaves, ff. '135-137', missing)
Quire 156-3 (ff. 138-140: 4th-6th leaves, ff. '141-143', missing)
Quire 168-1 (ff. 144-150: 8th leaf, f. '151', missing)
N.B. The presence of scribal leaf signatures shows that Quires 15-16 were originally a single quire of 16 leaves (4th and 12th-16th leaves missing). The current Quire 16 was originally bound after the 4th leaf of Quire 15, i.e. after the first stub following f. 140.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in Roman numerals in Quires 15 and 16 only (see Collation).

catchwords.seg: 'Catchwords seem to have been added at a late stage, when the manuscript had come to be regarded as in some sense finished and ready for binding, since they supply links not only within the booklets, but, on occasion, between one booklet and the next (e.g. those on ff. 17v and 81v). The positioning of some catchwords suggests that some leaves had already gone missing by this stage, for example those at the quire divisions at ff. 17v and 109v, where the lost folios '18' and '110' are represented merely by stubs.' Beadle (2017), p. 100

condition.p: The manuscript is soiled and badly damaged in parts, with many leaves missing. The extremely fragmentary remains of ff. 63-65 have been repaired and remounted, and ff. 66-74 show signs of heavy repair. One worm hole starts at f. 91, with over ten worm holes appearing in the final f. 150.

layout.seg: Frame ruling in plummet visible only in Booklet 4 (ff. ff. 82-123); possible hardpoint ruling of bounding lines elsewhere. Almost entirely in single columns (except for list of contents on ff. 19r-19v (2 columns) and list of terms of association on ff. 44v-45r (three columns) and spices on f. 45r (two columns)). Variable number of written lines.

handNote.p: 'As regards handwriting, Ll.1.18 at first gives the impression that it was the work of many hands, but (apart from very minor marginal additions) there were in fact only three: A, who wrote the bulk of the manuscript, probably over a period of time; B, who collaborated fleetingly with A early on, and who reappears to contribute a short later addition; and C, who appears in one quire only, a distinct booklet that A took into his compilation, and went on to use himself. Hand A's successive stints are often clearly discernible in frequent changes of pen or ink (or both), and his work shows signs of having been carried on intermittently, and probably in informal circumstances, as exemplars sporadically became available. The hands of all three scribes show variable mixtures of current anglicana and secretary features characteristic of the latter half of the fifteenth century, and both the duct and the selection of features in A's contributions were clearly affected by language, text type and the space available on the page.'

list.item: Booklet 1: Hand A throughout, except for f. 16v and part of 17r, by Hand B
Booklet 4: Hand A throughout, except for the recipe for sweating sickness added to f. 130v by Hand B
Booklet 5: Hand C throughout, except for ff. 149v-150v, where Hand A reappears

handNote.p: Further commentary on the scribal stints, arising from the 'Scriptorium' project (2006-2009):

Hand A wrote Items 1-4; Item 6 (f. 16r only; remainder by a different hand); Items 7–32, 42-43. In Item 28, ff. 89r (lower half) to 92v and ff. 103r to 123v are in one of hand A's normal styles; ff. 82r–89r (upper half) and 94r–102v are probably by the same hand, writing to a smaller module, and selecting certain different letter-forms (notably 'g'). It is possible that different types of texts, and the switch from English to Latin, might have been an influence on A's ductus and choice of letter-forms. Consider, for instance, the final stage of Item 4 (f. 13v) and the following Item 5 on f. 14r. The Latin is slightly more spaciously layed out; we find an occasional alternative form of 'd' (straight rather than a looped ascender); however, this is clearly still the work of Hand A. Another example is the transition from Item 15 to 16: for the latter item A's writing speed increases, resulting in larger letter forms, the flattening of the minims of 'm' and 'n' almost to zigzag lines, and very open 'e'. Hand A here fits fewer words to the line, and fewer lines to the pages, suggesting that time was a factor in copying this text. The hunting cries in this section have been more carefully set out, and thus they visually stand out.

Hand B is responsible for the continuation of Item 6 (ff. 16v-17r), and perhaps also for Item 33 (f. 130v). This hand shows a distinct looped 'g', a broken stroke in the bowl of 'd', and much less frequent use of backwards 'e'. Item 32 shows a similar formation of 'g' and word-final sigmoid 's'. Further contrasting letterforms between Hands A and B may be seen in the formation of Hand A's looped 'w' versus the near-straight strokes of Hand B's initial 'w'.

Hand C wrote items 35-42. This hand is somewhat flatter in appearance and less carefully formed than Hand A. Hand C has a notable tendency to fill out the remainder of his line with a horizontal stroke.

Finally, several other hands have added small items to the manuscript, such as Item 4 on f. 4v. The crossed-out section on f. 79v appears to be a later addition, though it shows some resemblance to Hand B's contribution on ff. 16v-17r. Even more minor notes and marginal glosses (for instance ff. 54r, 61r, 79r, 91v, 92r, 126r) may be the work of later readers or owners.

decoNote.p: Folios 131r-133v feature crude pen-and-ink renderings of coats of arms, illustrating the notes from Nicholas Upton's De re militari.

note.p: Notes in pencil by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886)Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886, concerning the loss of leaves from the manuscript, usually written in the corners of the lower margin (see. ff. 4v, 13v, 63r, 72v, 145r, 150v).

Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink Pink, H. L. (rear pastedown). From Quire 5 onwards, and continuing a sequence begun by an earlier, probably 19th-century hand, Pink also added quire numbers to the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf of each quire, and '+' in the same location to the first leaf of the second half of each quire. Pink also made notes throughout the manuscript, in locations where he judged leaves to be missing (see, for example, the upper margins of ff. 3r, 17v, 26v etc).

binding.p: Marbled paper cover over pasteboards, parchment tips, half calf, red leather spine. Probably 1950s/1960s.
Spine label from an ?18th-century binding preserved on the front pastedown.

origin.origDate: 15th century, probably compiled over a period of time during the later 3rd and 4th quarters of the century.
origin.p: As Keiser (1999) has pointed out, the later copies of legal instruments in Item 28 make frequent reference to William Booth or Bothe (d. 1464), bishop of Coventry and Lichfield and later archbishop of York, and to others associated with him, notably members of the Worsley family. The appearance of the handwriting, and the possible dating of some of the watermarks to c. 1469 and c. 1477, tend to suggest that the manuscript may have been compiled over a period during the last quarter of the fifteenth century. The fact that Scribe C, who must have added item 27 at a date after 1483 (when the sweating sickness first appeared in England) also collaborated with Scribe A in the copying of item 6, lends substantial support to this suggestion.

Items 26, 28 and 32 strongly suggest that the principal compiler of the manuscript (Scribe A) was a member or servant of the religious community at the collegiate church of Southwell, near Newark, in Nottinghamshire. In order to compile Item 28 he must have had access to the archive of William Booth, who often stayed at the archiepiscopal residence at Southwell, and in whose church he was buried in 1464. Item 26 indicates that the compiler was directly associated with a member of the Worsley family family, whose extensive connections with the community at Southwell (and with Booth) are evident in Item 28, and more generally in the Southwell visitation records of the later fifteenth century (printed by Leach (1891)). Regarding the contents of the manuscript, it is relevant to note that hawking and hunting were amongst the clerical misdemeanours identified during the visitations, and that there are also allusions to the fact that the community was troubled by plague from time to time.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 114 (f. 3r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on front pastedown.

recordHist.source: A description of this manuscript and a transcription of part of its text was produced by Verweij, SebastiaanSebastiaan Verweij as part of Scriptorium: Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Online (2006-09), a three-year AHRC-funded Resource Enhancement Project based in the Faculty of English at the University of Cambridge. The digital images, descriptive metadata and transcriptions from this project have been archived on Apollo, the University of Cambridge's Digital Repository, and have also been made available via a dedicated collection page on the Cambridge Digital Library.
recordHist.change: The description of the manuscript was revised in 2024 by Freeman, James, 1984- James Freeman, as part of Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, a two-year Wellcome-funded Research Resources Project based at Cambridge University Library. The revised description draws on the study of the manuscript in Richard Beadle, 'Cambridge, University Library, MS Ll.1.18: a Southwell miscellany', in Pursuing Middle English manuscripts and their texts: essays in honour of Ralph Hanna, ed. by S. Horobin and A. Nafde (2017), pp. 99-112 and on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose 19 (2009), pp. 312-19.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

projectDesc.p: The transcription and an earlier version of this description were created for Scriptorium: Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Online (see Source for further details).

div.p:
Afuge tu subito procul esto tarde redito
Aufuge pesto cite procul
et tarde reuenito
Fly sone fro the pestilens fly . fly forþer ayen do not h.y
Mox procul a peste tu fuge . vix reueni

div.head:
Hyt is to be Remembret off þe dayly
dietez in lordes and ladies howsez
For to be kepette
Dietes pro die dominica
div.p:
þat is to say on sunday for my lordez or ladyes
bred & ale suche as þayre state askez potage
such as þe stuward wyll assigne and by þe
cokez aduise Martynmas beefe lard powdered
beefe capon rosted or boylette as ceson off þe
ȝere askez (pour secund cours) Suche po -
tage as þe sesoun off þe yere askez þt is to
say bytwene paschez and qwysonday iossell
fro qwyssonday to michelmas charlette forsette
or vnforsette as þe cas requireth and after þe
astatez repayre so by þe aduise off þe cokez
to chaunge in to better potage And forther
more iij maner off rostez wyth a frytour or
a frenchmoll or a bakyn mete after
discrecioun
off þe stuward wyth thaduise off þe coke
Than as for howsald potage martynmas
beefe and powdered beefe wyth podynges
yff þay be hade for þe fyrst cowrse for gen
tylmen & gentyll wemen
(pour secound
cours ij maner rostez A bakenmete A frytour

Or a frenchemole & for yemen
sum rost A frytour or a
bakyn mete or a frenchemoll

Pro die lune:
Monday for potage grewell boylyd mete for my
lord or lady podyngs or a calfe hede martis
f befe
powderyd befe vele or muton rosted chekenes or peions
hot rostyd Conyng þe gentylwemen
in þe chamber
i rost wt þe peions And no secound cowrse And þe
howsald þt is to say gentilmen
foyre
martis befe bacon
And fayr powder befe at none wtouten more at
euyn for my lord & lady knokelys of befe vele bolyd
chekyns wt iij maners of diuers rostes gentilmen &
gentilwemen ij dyuers rostes & yemen on rost

Pro die martis:
Apon teusday potage martis befe larde or porke or
muton boyllyd capon rost or boylled yf strangeres come
at þe secund cowrse no potage bot yf strangers come
pyg or vele or muton chekenes or peions or
bakyn mete a frenchemole or a frytour so þer be iij
disches at þe lest for gel gentillmen & women at þe
first cowrse potage martis befe powdered befe to geder
wt podyng yf þay bee had at þe secund cowrse pyg
wele or muton so þer be two rosted at þe lest or for
lak of a rost a franchemand or a bakyn mete or
A frytour for yemen
in þe hall potage martis befe powdered
befe lewyd schulder of muton or brest of wele chekyn
or peion A froyse or a tansay wt a petite[?] or a forse or
a tansay gentilmen & wemen befe lechyd moton rost
wt a petite[?] a froyse or a tansay yemen befe leched
& moton rostet wt a tansay all in a dych

Pro die marcurij:
On þe wedensday þe
seruice like to þe maner ay as for
þe lord & lady and as to þe howsald trypes boyled
and non other rost as at soper

pro die iovis:
Opon thoresday lyke to tuesday Neuer þe lesse all days
in þe weke þe cermoe most be changet after þe aft of
strangeres yf þay come

pro die veneris & die satvrni :
Frayday & Seterday & all sych days potage & iij or iiij
dysches of stuffe of howsald at þe fyrst cowrse for
þe heȝe lord at þe secunde cowrse potage wt iiij or v disches
of fresch fysche yf þai be hade ientilmen & wemen
heryng salt fych & stokke fych at þe first cowrse at
þe secunde cowrse ij dyuerse frech fysches yemen potage
heryng salt fych wt on maner of fresch serue al at
a cowrse & yf strawngeres come on fych days to
be serued as þe case askez & þayreafte askez Not wych
stondyng þis A poyntement

div.head:
Here Begynneth the Rewle and the Ordinance off sleying
off almaner wyldfole off hole fote and clofe fote and saw
syng for hem and the sleyng off fawre foted bestez and -
the sawsyng for hem etcetera
div.p: For Crane

Take a crane & lette hym blode in þe Rofe off þe mowth
scalde hym and draw hym atte þe vent trusse vp
hys legges cut off the wynges atte the ioynt next the
body and þan kut away hys nekke by the body and
Rost hym as a pohenne & Rayes hys thyes & his legg es
wynges as a pohen and sawse for hym camelyn Or
elles to make sawse for hym take white brede and toste
hyt on a gyrdyrn and stepe hit in vynegre and draw
hyt thoro a straynour wt mustard put therto pouder
gynger & synamon
sugre þe moste parte & rayse þe wynges & thyes as a gose
For Swanne or wyld goos/

Take a swanne & kutte hym in the rofe of þe mouth
kepe his blode to colour with the chawdon or ellez
knytte his nekke scalde hym & roste hym as a gose & sawse
for hym is chawdon hote.
For to make chawdon

Take therto off þe swanne or wylde goos the geserne the
armys slyt hem & shave hem clene the wynges and
the fete & whan yt is soden pyke away þe bonez and
hew hit small and put hyt in a potte and boyle hyt
with þe same brothe and drawe a lyre off brede wyth
Rede wyne and alay hyt vp þerwith seson hyt vp with
pouder
peper
gynger & salt colour hit wt his owne blode or
wt sandres þat yt be browne take owte þe smale bonez
off the fete and lette þe skyn stande hole & lay a fote
in a dyssh and poure the chawdon a boue & serue hit forthe
For pohen

Take a pohen & breke hys nekke by the body & saue
the skynne & the hede hole draw hym & scalde hym
& lette his leggez be on & Roste hym as an henne
& Reyse the thyes & wynges as a henne & yff þu wylt
when he is rostet put the skyn and the hede wyth

the fedyrs on the nekke for the difference fro a capon &
serue hym forthe sawce for hym mustarde sugre and a ly
tyll salte & take þe same for the Fesaunt

div.head:
Here Begynneth the sleyinge off Fysschis And the sethynge
and the sawcynge off hem as yt is here after wryton
div.p: For codlynge hake or haddok

Take & drawe hym and cutte hym owtewerd in Rounde
peces but not the haddok and cut off the hede off the
hake or codlynge yff hit be large & cut owte a fayre
tayle thenne sethe hym in water & salt & when hyt
boyles skemme hit clene thenne cast in þi fyssh & parcelly
With the lyuer & when he is soden serue hym forthe with
his lyuer a boue sauce hym wt hys lyuer vergeous mustard pouder
peper
For fressh samon

Take & chyne hym sethe hym in water salte ale parcyll
and sethe hym ynowghe & serue hym forthe colde sawce
for hym grene sawce in tyme off yeire or ellez venegre
pouder
gynger
synamon or ellis chawdon for hym made off hys
awne kynde as es specifiet on þe oþer syde off þe leve
For Gurnarde

Take & drawe hym by the side benethe þe gylle saue
the sounde hole the refete wtyn hym slyt þe poke shave
hit clene sethe hym in water & salt at þe boylynge cast
ynne thy fyssh and when yt is boylet yo ynogh take
hit vp serue hym forthe sawce for hym vinegre & peper
Soles boylette

Take a sole draw hym vnderneth the fynne benethe
the gyll butte lette the hede be on sethe hym in water
salte serve hym forthe sawce wt vynegre pouder
gynger
and yff þu wylt brewle hym sawce hym in þe same maner
Chynes off fressh samon brewlet

Take & brewle hem on a gryndyrn and make a syrpe
off venegre pouder
peper & synamon and serue hem forthe
powre þe syryp a bouen
Congre boylet

Take and scalde a congur put not yn to hote water
for brestyng cut off þe hede drawe hym a lytyll be
fore þe navyll by þe baly and lose þe guttes take
hem owte atte the throte the lyuer therwyth cut all þe
bely in Rounde peces outwarde shave away þe herys

fro the bakke and off the bely vnto þe tayle thenne boy
le hym tyll he be ynogh take hit vp lay yt yn A vessell
with water salte And serue hym forthe colde wt levys off
par cell strewed a boue And brewle the hede yiff þu wylt
sauce for hym pouder
peper & venegre and for the boylette
congre butte vinegre
The letter in mirror writing, which lacks only the formula 'have you in his keeping' and the writer's signature at the end, reads:

mester worsseley I recomande me to you prayng you to be good master to thomas kyd
vorth and ye shall haue thomas staunton ser ues for euer no more but jesus

The code in line four employs normal consonants, but substitutes each vowel with a 'p'-like mark, and the number of strokes through the descender indicate its value. Thus, 1 stroke is 'a', 2 strokes is 'e', three strokes is 'i', four strokes is 'o', and five strokes is 'u' . The code employed for the third line on this page is somewhat more obscure, and substitutes letterforms with symbols. This line can be reconstructed, however, as it reads the same as line four. For further references to the Worseley family, see items 22 and 23.
master uorssele I prae you to speke uet me
master uorssele I prae you to speke uet me
